Description: A pottery flask with flattened circular body and a short neck, flaring mouth, and two handles with small knobs at the lower spring; two small half-cylinder feet are placed at the bottom: the vessel does not stand. Both sides have the same relief decoration, but they probably stem from different moulds. The patterns lie in concentric zones, with a plain band near the edge, the outer part defined by a narrow ladder-pattern; within is a wreath-band edged with plain mouldings; this encloses a rosette with angular petals and the tips of rounded petals showing between them; at the centre is a small rosette. Pendent from the neck of the vessel is a 'necklace' with a rounded pendant. Two-piece mould. Dark-grey Nile silt with some mica, covered with a black slip: Memphis Black Ware.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired at Saqqara. Ptolemaic, late third to second century BC. Comparanda: Close and near: Christie's New York 'Sale Catalogue', 5 June 1998: lot 93; Edgar 1911: pl. xxiv:26301; Graindor 1939: pl. xxxii:92, My´sliwiec and Bakr Said 1999: 197, fig. 14b, from pottery workshops at Athribis: context second century BC; Petrie et al. 1910: pl. xxxvii:53, from Memphis, 'from a heap of fragments from a factory north-east of the glazing kilns', presumably near Kom Helul; Seif el-Din 2006: pl. 6:1 and 2. Bibliog: Seif el-Din 2006: pl. 7:2, no. 21.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3647)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
